thread.title: Meghan McCain Blasts WikiLeaks For Compromising National Security
thread.title_full: Meghan McCain Blasts WikiLeaks For Compromising National Security

author: Andrew Kerr
title: Meghan McCain Blasts WikiLeaks For Compromising National Security

organizations.name: wikileaks for compromising national security meghan mccain blasts wikileaks for compromising national security

text:
Meghan McCain Blasts WikiLeaks For Compromising National Security "Everyone knows this is what they do." by Andrew Kerr March 8, 2017 at 3:03pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Wikileaks released “Vault 7” Tuesday, a trove of documents revealing the CIA’s ability to hack everything from smartphones to smart televisions. 
While many have expressed concern about the CIA’s ability to snoop, Meghan McCain argued on Fox News’ Outnumbered Wednesday that the real issue is the leaks themselves. 
“Who is surprised that the CIA uses covert operations to infiltrate espionage?” McCain asked. “Duh! Watch one James Bond movie! Everyone knows this is what they do.” Advertisement - story continues below 
“The fact you are showing … exactly how they do it, you are making our national security less safe,” McCain argued. 
Brian Kilmeade chimed in as well, saying that he was “unbelievably concerned” about the Vault 7 leaks. Advertisement - story continues below 
“I believe most people say that are in the know that this is worse than Edward Snowden and what he gave away, because it tells us how we do things,” Kilmeade said. 
“It gives other nations a sense of we can’t be trusted because we can’t control our own intelligence apparatus,” he argued. “It’s astounding how devastating this is.” 
Technology experts have their own concerns about the leaks, which claim that the CIA chose not to notify technology companies of known vulnerabilities. 
Kevin Bankston, director of the New America Foundation’s Open Technology Institute, argues that the CIA “stockpiling a bunch of vulnerabilities is bad for cybersecurity.” Advertisement - story continues below
